content: The "Electricity Reliability and Fuel Security Act" establishes a federal tax credit for coal-powered electric generation units under section 45T of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit for coal-powered electric generation units is determined as 30% of qualified expenses or $13 multiplied by the unit's capacity rating in kilowatts. The tax credit for coal-powered electric generation units is calculated as 30% of qualified expenses or $13 multiplied by the unit's capacity rating in kilowatts. Qualified expenses refer to costs for operating or maintaining the unit, excluding expenses for coal. Public entities can transfer this credit. Public entities can transfer this credit to eligible project partners. The tax credit for coal-powered electric generation units can be transferred by public entities to eligible project partners who elect to apply for the credit. A qualified public entity is defined as a government entity or a mutual/cooperative electric company. The tax credit for coal-powered electric generation units can be transferred by public entities to eligible project partners, including government entities, mutual/cooperative electric companies, and not-for-profit electric utilities that received a loan under the Rural Electrification Act of 1936. Eligible project partners for coal-powered electric generation units include those responsible for operating, maintaining, or repairing the unit, as well as those involved in providing coal to the unit. The term 'eligible project partner' for coal-powered electric generation units includes those responsible for operating, maintaining, repairing, providing coal, financing, or leasing the unit. Special rules apply to partnerships, where a qualified public entity is treated as the taxpayer for the entity's distributive share of the credit. The term 'eligible project partner' includes partners of the partnership for the credit, with a qualified public entity treated as the taxpayer for their share. The credit is taken into account in the taxable year when an election is made. The term 'eligible project partner' includes any partner of the partnership. The credit is taken into account in the first taxable year of the eligible project partner after the qualified public entity's taxable year. The credit for eligible project partners is taken into account in the first taxable year after the qualified public entity's taxable year. Any benefit from this credit is not considered a private business use. Basis adjustment applies for this credit. For section 141(b)(1), benefits from an eligible project partner's election are not considered private business use. A basis adjustment applies if a credit is allowed for a coal-powered electric generation unit. This section applies to taxable years from 2018 to 2022. The basis of property for a coal-powered electric generation unit is reduced by the credit allowed. This section applies to taxable years from 2018 to 2022 and includes a conforming amendment to the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a credit against alternative minimum tax for coal-powered electric generation units.
